prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RN88 Band 7 CO3-2 and 13CO 3-2 and continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Lines 12CO and 13CO 3-2 BW 234.375 MHz Continuum 2GHz at 331.6 GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
APEX 13CO (3-2) peak antenna temperature is 0.3K. Assuming a 5" disk with a uniform temperature and allowing for beam dilution this corresponds to 4K. The required 0.2K rms allows this line to be mapped with a high S/N. The temperature is probably not uniform over the disk so the maximum S/N will be even higher. The 12CO 3-2 APEX peak antenna temperature is 0.6K so this line will be detected with a even higher S.N ratio. The S/N ratios and integration times of OT and the Sensitivity calculator agree.
The source continuum flux is not known but the observations will probe for a possible protoplanetary source.
The expected line intensities in the source are high and therefore only short on source integration time is required. The overheads are however long. Alma observations are required because of the spatial resolution.
The size of the source is 6" and no ACA is required.

APEX 13CO 2-1 peak antenna temperature is 0.3K. Assuming a 5" disk with a uniform temperature and allowing for beam dilution this corresponds to 9K. If C18O 2-1 line is optically thin the required 0.4K rms allows also this line to be detected with a S/N of approximately 3. The temperature is probably not uniform over the disk so the maximum S/N will be even higher. The 12CO 2-1 APEX peak antenna temperature is 0.6K so this line will be detected with a high S.N ratio. The source can be mapped with a good s/n in 12co and 13co. The S/N ratios and integration times of OT and the Sensitivity calculator agree.
The expected line intensities in the source are high and therefore only short on source integration time is required. The overheads are however long. Alma observations are required because of the spatial resolution.
The size of the source is 5" and ACA is not required.
We want to observe the three CO (2-1) isotopoloques (12CO, 13CO and C18O) simultaneously with a 0.1 km/s velocity resolution (the APEX line width is 0.9 km/s). The data rate has been lowered by adding up channels. However, the narrowest band widths for 12CO and 13CO can not be chosen as according to OT the bands would end up at a noisy part of the reciever. The data rate given by OT in this case is however 6.79 MB/s exceeding the average data rate of 6MB/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RN122 Band 7 CO 3-2 and 13CO 3-2 and continuum

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
APEX 13CO (3-2) peak antenna temperature is 0.6K. Assuming a 5" disk with a uniform temperature and allowing for beam dilution this corresponds to 8K. the required 0.4K rms allows this line to be mapped with a high S/N. The temperature is probably not uniform over the disk so the maximum S/N will be even higher. The 12CO 2-1 APEX peak antenna temperature is 0.9K so this line will be detected with a even higher S.N ratio. The S/N ratios and integration times of OT and the Sensitivity calculator agree.
The three 12CO (2-1) velocity components in RN122 are not expected to coincide spatially. The main velocity component comes from the compact head and the two blueshifted components from the tail. However, ACA, as suggested by OT, will be used.
The source continuum flux is not known but the observations will probe for a possible protoplanetary source.
The expected line intensities in the source are high and therefore only short on source integration time is required. The overheads are however long. Alma observations are required because of the spatial resolution.

APEX 13co 2-1 peak antenna temperature is 0.6K. Assuming a 5" disk with a uniform temperature and adding the same contribution from the tail and beam dilution this corresponds to 9K. Assuming C18O 2-1 is optically thin the required 0.4K rms allows also this line to be detected with a S/N of approximately 4. The temperature is probably not uniform over the disk so the maximum S/N will be even higher. The source can be mapped with a good S/N. The 12CO 2-1 APEX peak antenna temperature is 0.9K so this line will be detected with a high S.N ratio. The S/N ratios and integration times of OT and the Sensitivity calculator agree.
The three 12CO (2-1) velocity components in RN122 are not expected to coincide spatially. The main velocity component comes from the compact head and the two blueshifted components from the tail. Their respective sizes are expected to be smaller than 11", the largest detectable structure of the 12m array at his frequency. The source continuum flux is not known but the observations will probe for a possible protoplanetary source.
The expected line intensities in the source are high and therefore only short on source integration time is required. The overheads are however long. Alma observations are required because of the spatial resolution.
The source has a compact 6" symmetric head and an elongated, less dense 12" long tail. The single dish CO (2-1) spectra show three distinctive velocity components of which the two weaker ones are separated by one and three km/s from the strongest component. The observed single dish velocity and line structure is such that it is highly unlikely that one or more velocity compenents would cover the whole extent of the source and thus three distictive condensations are expected (Radiation Driven Implosion is the likely formation mechanism for the source). Thus the source can be observed using two single ALMA band 6 pointings and no ACA observations is needed. However, if such extended emission is present, it will be detected in the band 7 observation which includes ACA. The size of hte condensations could be be larger than 7", the band 7 resolution limit.
We want to observe the three CO (2-1) isotopoloques (12CO, 13CO and C18O) simultaneously with a 0.1 km/s velocity resolution (the APEX line width is 0.9 km/s). The data rate has been lowered by adding up channels. However, the narrowest band widths for 12CO and 13CO can not be chosen as according to OT the bands would end up at a noisy part of the reciever. The data rate given by OT with the selected setup is however 6.79 MB/s exceeding slightly the average data rate of 6MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The total number of unbound low-mass free-floating planetary-mass objects in interstellar space in the Milky Way could several hundred billions. Gahm et~al. (2007) proposed that globulettes could be one source seeding the Milky Way with these low mass objects. Globulettes are extremely small (average size 2.5~kAU), round, and cold molecular clumps of planetary to brown dwarf mass that are silhouetted as dark spots against the background of nebular emission in expanding H II regions surrounding massive star-forming regions. We have studied the Rosette Nebula globulettes using NIR imaging and (sub)mm molecular line observations. The strong CO emission observed in the globulettes encourages us to continue the studies using ALMA. We want to observe two small size globulettes in CO 3--2 and 2--1 transitions (and isotopologues). The data will be analyzed using 3D non-LTE radiation transfer program and with an advanced astrochemical {\sc 3d-pdr} code. We will be able to produce unprecedentedly seen synthetic observations which will be compared with the observational data thus offering a deeper understanding of the physical and chemical properties of globulettes.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
